awd_titl_txt: Integrating Computing Across the Curriculum (ICAC): Incorporating Technology into STEM Education Using XO Laptops
awd_abstract_narration:
The ICAC builds and tests applications tied to the school curriculum that integrate the sciences with mathematics, computational thinking, reading and writing in elementary schools.  The investigative core of the project is to determine how one-computer-per-child can be implemented in such a way as to support STEM learning and lead more urban children to STEM career paths. Data are collected both on the process of adoption and on the outcomes of learning and entering career paths, as measured by course selection and interests.

Building on a state effort that has provided XO laptop computers to every child in grades 1-5, ICAC provides approximately 160 teachers and 8000 students with computer resources and skills and supports the adoption so as to increase the number of students in the STEM pipeline.  The community served by the project is an urban, predominantly African American, high poverty school system where students are underrepresented in the STEM pipeline.  The project advances computing, science, and mathematics skills of 4th and 5th grade Birmingham City Schools (BCS) teachers and students, works with teachers to develop curriculum, and provides professional development for teachers, and facilitates participation and support by administrators.  In addition, ICAC provides more extensive training to 320 students, drawn from each school, who become resources for the teachers and their fellow students.  ICAC engages parents so that they understand the opportunities available for their children in STEM-centered careers and so that the parents can be supportive of their child's interest in STEM education.

Integrating Computing Across the Curriculum

How can we help young predominantly minority students become more interested in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math (STEM) fields?

STEM fields have become increasingly important for our society and the world. As a result, there is a growing need for a highly skilled and educated workforce of individuals in the various STEM fields. Unfortunately, there exists a persistent “STEM divide” in the United States as minorities have remained traditionally underrepresented in these fields. The present project sought to reduce the STEM divide by harnessing the resources already available in schools in unique and innovative ways.

The Integrating Computing Across the Curriculum (ICAC) project was a multidisciplinary project with the primary goal of increasing the number of minority students interested in STEM fields. To be more specific, ICAC was a project that provided teachers and students with the skills needed to enhance STEM education in their elementary school classrooms. Classroom computer access has opened an exciting new dimension for STEM education; however, simply providing students with computer access is not enough. The ICAC project helped realize the full potential of using computers as tools for advancing STEM education by developing methods that enabled classroom computing to serve as a bridge across the STEM disciplines.

ICAC transformed fourth and fifth-grade classrooms into technology-enriched learning environments by integrating computing across the elementary school disciplines. ICAC’s interventions targeted two groups: teachers and students. During the course of this five year project, the ICAC team worked with 30 schools, 184 teachers, and 4,193 students in a high poverty school system in Alabama. In order to reach students, the ICAC project sought to increase teachers’ computing in their classrooms. The ICAC project obtained participation from school administrators, teachers, students, and parents over the course of the intervention. The ICAC intervention itself included planning meetings with principals, professional development opportunities for fourth and fifth-grade teachers, in-class support for teachers, summer computing camps, and after-school computing clubs for fourth and fifth-grade students. ICAC began with only 2 schools in the Birmingham City School District and then scaled each year (year 2: 6 schools; year 3: 10 schools; year 4: 12 schools).  

In the end, we learned a great deal from the ICAC project. A number of studies have been published using the ICAC data which have contributed to our understanding of the factors that influence young predominantly minority students’ self-confidence, academic motivations, and STEM interest. For instance, we found that it is possible to increase students' positive attitudes toward computer use through an intervention aimed at their teachers. Another study found that students’ future expectations and personal values were associated with their positive STEM attitudes. Meanwhile, students’ anxiety and stress while using computers was associated with students’ negative STEM attitudes. Furthermore, we found that when students’ had positive hands on experiences using computers or when they simply observed their teachers using computers, students’ self-confidence using technology increased. We also found that playing digital games and talking to friends online can actually help increase minority students’ technology self-confidence. Therefore, entertaining computer based activities in the classroom can actually help students become more comfortable and confident with technology and STEM careers. These are just some of the ways in which the ICAC project impacted our scientific understanding of minority students’ STEM attitudes.

Regarding minority students’ STEM interest, we suggest that future computing interventions should focus on enhancing students’ academic values and expectations for success in STEM fields. By increasing the practical value minority students place on STEM education, and their ability to succeed in STEM fields, they may be more likely to pursue higher education and STEM careers. Furthermore, future computing interventions should also help reduce minority students’ computer stress and anxiety, which can serve as a barrier towards STEM careers, by providing positive hands on experiences. Last but not least, future computing interventions should consider establishing dedicated “computer recess” time to help minority students increase their technology related self-confidence. Allowing minority students a chance to “play” with technology gives them increased opportunities to build their computer self-confidence and reduce their stress and anxiety when using computers.

For successful technology adoption in schools, continued support must be made available to teachers, students, and parents. When provided with proper training, support, and resources, we found that the majority of teachers were willing to integrate computing across their curriculum. However, organizational cultures and turnover impacted the successful update of this initiative. Changes in the organizational leadership in the school system and individual schools made it harder to have successful integration in some schools. Researchers have no control over these changes and have to adapt when they occur. Working closely with school system partners will help ensure that momentum and progress continue in technology integration projects.
